body.p: TRANSLATION OF THE BIBLE
TO BE PUBLISHED BY
The Jewish Publication Society of America
REV. DR. M. JASTROW,
Editor,
139 W. Upsal St., Germantown,
Revision Committee

p.persName: REV. DR. F. DE SOLA MENDES

body.p: INSTRUCTIONS
TO THE TRANSLATORS

The new translation of the Bible has been undertaken with the object of obtaining a
version of the Holy Scriptures, which, while taking full account of the results of modern
research, shall be characterized by the simplicity of a book to be used in the home and at
public worship. As the Jew considers the original text alone invested with authority, it should
be our aim to approach it as nearly as possible, and for that purpose we should avail ourselves
of the extensive fund of traditional and philological interpretations in our possession.

(I) Inasmuch as some basis must be adopted to secure uniformity of style, and as
the only complete English translation prepared for Jews and embodying Jewish traditions
and conceptions is that known as the Leeser Bible, this version has been chosen to serve
as a foundation for the proposed work. At the same time the translators are expected to
consult the “Authorized Version” and the “Revised Version,” the former as the undisputed
guide for diction and the rhythmic flow of language, the latter because of its correction of
many erroneous renderings in the older versions in accordance with the advance of scholar-
ship since the days of King James. After the Editor and the Revision Committee have
done their work, it will be handed over to the style editors for final revision.

(2) Whenever a departure from the usual conception of a passage or word is made,
the reasons should be briefly stated to the editor. If found necessary, they will be
printed in an appendix of notes at the end of the whole book. It should be borne in
mind, however, that certain poetical expressions, correct and incorrect ones (as e. g., “the
valley of the shadow of death”), are so firmly rooted in literature that a change would
be a loss.

(3) In view of the recent investigations in the departments of Hebrew philology and
biblical exegesis, it will be necessary to compare carefully the new commentaries with the
older ones for every verse—the method that has given value to the English-American
Revised Version of the King James Bible. In this connection the following works will be
found helpful:

Die heiligen Schriften des Alten Testaments, by KAUTZSCH (Mohr, Freiburg),
embodies the opinions of the best commentators.

Gesenius' Hebräisches u. Aramäisches Handwörterbuch über d. A. T. (12th
edition. Leipzig, 1895).

Siegfried und Stade's Hebräisches Wörterbuch zum A. T. (Veit & Co., Leipzig,
1893)
Hebrew and English Lexicon, by BROWN, DRIVER and BRIGGS (in course of publication).

For the Post-Biblical Hebrew and the Chaldaic in Talmud and Midrash, the following are
recommended:
LEVY'S Neuhebräisches und Chaldäisches Wörterbuch (Brockhaus, Leipzig, 1876-1889).
KOHUT'S Arukh ha-Shalem (Wien, 1878-1892).

JASTROW'S Dictionary of the Targumim, Talmud Babli and Yerushalmi, etc.,
as far as published (Luzac & Co., London; G. P. Putnam's Sons, New York).

(4) It is urged that Anglo-Saxon words be used in preference to those of Latin
origin, whenever the former are consistent with clearness. The older forms of such words
as honour, favour (instead of honor, favor), etc., will be used in the work.

(5) For proper names the form familiar by long usage should be employed, as Ahab
(not Achab), Absalom (not Abshalom), Gideon (not Gid'on), Joash (not Yoash), Baal (not
Ba'al), etc., etc.

(6) For Hebrew use “Lord;” for Hebrew use “God;” for Hebrew use “nether world.” In trans-
lating Hebrew, Hebrew, Hebrew, and similar words, the context should be consulted carefully, and choice
made of the most appropriate rendering among those offered.

(7) As a rule the “Keri” should be followed in preference to the “Kethib.” If
necessary, the latter may be embodied in a note.

(8) When the text is obscure, the words “Text obscure,” “Attempted Translation,”
or some other indication of uncertainty, should be added in a note (to be embodied in
the appendix). Whenever an emendation of the text on recognized authority is deemed
unavoidable or desirable, the reasons therefor should be briefly stated in a note to the
editor, who, with his associates, the members of the Revision Committee, reserves the
right to adopt or reject such suggestions, and will assume the responsibility for the
final result.

(9) Explanations of proper names are to be marked by square [ ] brackets; words
supplying an omission in the Hebrew text by angle < > brackets. Italics and parentheses
should be employed according to ordinary usage, not as in the “Authorized Version.”

(10) The chapter and verse divisions of the Massoretic text are to be preserved; also
the Hebrew and the English titles of the books. The Pentateuchal portions (Sidroth) are
to appear in Hebrew type.

(11) A division into subject-paragraphs, similar to that of the Revised Version, is to
be adopted. The main contents of each paragraph are to be expressed by the translators
in brief sentences to serve as running titles for each page. The above mentioned work of
Kautzsch (Die heiligen Schriften des Alten Testaments) is a valuable guide for this por-
tion of the work.

(12) In all the books, the poetical portions are to be arranged in lines according to
the mode of the “Revised Version.”

(13) For the Massoretic text, the edition of Baer and Delitssch (as far as published)
is recommended.

(14) Besides special works upon the book assigned to each contributor, the following
general commentaries are recommended:
Lange's Theologisch-Homiletisches Bibelwerk (American edition by SCHAFF).
Kurzgefasstes exegetisches Handbuch zum Alten Testament, by HIRZEL (Leipzig).
Handkommentar zum Alten Testament, by NOWACK, (Göttingen, 1892-1895).

Kurzgefasster Kommentar zu d. heil. Schriften des Alten Testaments, by
STRACK and ZOECKLER (München, 1886-1894).

Biblischer Kommentar über das Alte Testament, by KEIL and DELITZSCH (Leip-
zig, 1861-1893).

p.hi: The Cambridge Bible for Schools and Colleges.

body.p: The Expositor's Bible (London, 1888-1894).

International Critical Commentary, by PLUMMER, BRIGGS and DRIVER (Scribner's
Sons, 1895, in course of publication).

(15) A careful study of Talmud and Midrash will be repaid by the discovery of
interpretations of biblical passages, direct or implied, which have hiterto been over-
looked, but which, it is believed, will recommend themselves to the judgment of scholars.
Such passages are made easily accessible through the handbook Hebrew
(Wilna, 1880), which points out where every biblical verse is quoted in Talmud Babli and
Yerushalmi, Midrashim, Yalkut Shim'oni, and other works of minor value for the purpose
in view. Attention is called to a list of abbreviations of book-titles and their explanations
in the front of the book, and to the appendix, Hebrew, which will facilitate the finding of
passages mentioned in the body of the book by reference to pages not alike in all editions.

(16) The books assigned to each translator, cut from a copy of the Leeser Bible, will
be sent, pasted on paper with wide margins for his emendations.

(17) Contributors are expected to hand in their work to the editor not later than
August 1, 1897. In order, however, to facilitate the work of revision, they are urgently
requested to send in their work, or parts thereof, as soon as possible.

NOTE:—The compensation of contributors is $1.50 per printed page of the Leeser
Bible.
Attached find a provisional list of contributors and of the parts assigned to each.
PHILADELPHIA, February, 1896.
List of those Invited to Cooperate
Corresponding Members of the Revision Committee
REV. DR. HERMAN ADLER, London, England
REV. DR. ISAAC M. WISE, Cincinnati, O.
